episode_summary: This episode of "No Such Thing As A Fish" covers a variety of intriguing topics, including the irony of an author on gullibility falling for a Ponzi scheme, a Paralympian finding a shoe-sharing soulmate, the innovative use of fidget spinners for medical diagnostics, and Al Capone's charitable yet self-serving soup kitchen during the Great Depression.

facts.fact: Two days after receiving his latest book, the author of 'Annals of Gullibility: Why We Get Duped and How to Avoid It' lost hundreds of thousands of dollars in a Ponzi scheme.
In 2011, former Paralympian Josh Sundquist, who's missing his left leg, announced that he'd found his soulmate, i.e., someone missing a right leg with whom he can split pairs of shoes.
You can now diagnose a urinary tract infection using a fidget spinner.

Al Capone ran a soup kitchen during the Great Depression; he served beef on Thanksgiving in 1930 because there had just been a theft of 1,000 turkeys nearby and he didn't want the authorities to think it was him.
